page.title: 06AN ALSAGER SUPERMARKET
page.content: I went to a supermarket to interview a cashier. She said she liked her job and she would not like to change it. Sometimes 1,000 people came to shop in a day, she usually served about 300 people. Then I saw the lady who sold the cigarettes. She said about 200 people came in every day to buy cigarettes and that she sold about 2,000 each day. She also liked her job. She told us that the shop had been broken into two weeks before. The customers thought that the shop was often crowded and the service was too slow. They said the prices were very reasonable and that the shop sold the things most people used. Most of the customers called two or three times a week. By L. Horsham, S. Byrne and N. Ruddock
